render.tex: %text The lines $\ora{r}=\ora{a_1}+k\ora{b_1}$ and $\ora{r}=\ora{a_2}+k\ora{b_2}$ are coplanar (in the same plane) as long as $(\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1})$ is parallel to $(\ora{b_1}\times\ora{b_2})$ %

reason.tex:
%text $\ora{r}=\ora{a_1}+k\ora{b_1}$ represents a line passing through a point with position vector $\ora{a_1}$ and is parallel to $\ora{b_1}$. Similarly, $\ora{r}=\ora{a_2}+k\ora{b_2}$ represents a line passing through a point with position vector $\ora{a_2}$ and is parallel to $\ora{b_2}$.
If the lines are coplanar then, % \begin{align} (\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1}) & \text{ lies in the plane} \\ (\ora{b_1}\times \ora{b_2}) & \text{ is $\perp$ to the plane} \\ \therefore (\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1})&\text{ is $\perp$ to }(\ora{b_1}\times \ora{b_2}) \\ \implies(\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1})&\cdot\,(\ora{b_1}\times \ora{b_2})=0 \end{align} \\
